title: Invasion protest: ‘F*** Aussie pride’
text:
'Invasion Day' March in Redfern media_camera Greens MP David Shoebridge says we must not call it Australia Day. Picture: John Grainger 
Videos have emerged of people being arrested as the marchers descend on the city, and confrontation with police increases. 
A video captured by BuzzFeed’s Indigenous Affairs Reporter Allan Clarke shows the frightening moment the Invasion Day rally turned violent. The Sydney Invasion Day rally just turned violent. pic.twitter.com/F66rQIJ292 — Allan Clarke (@AllanJClarke) 26 January 2017 
And FIRE co-organiser Ken Canning said Australia Day is a scam. 
“It is not day to celebrate, it is not a day to throw a shrimp on the barbie or get blind drunk and throw up on the footpath,” Mr Canning said. 
He said he did not care about a young Aboriginal man burning an Australian flag last night. 
“I do not care. Why should I care, it should be put in perspective with what indigenous people have gone through,” he said. media_camera 3000 people are believed to have turned out at the Sydney “Invasion Day” rally. Picture: John Grainger media_camera FIRE co-organiser Ken Canning speaks at the "Invasion Day" rally in Redfern. Picture: John Grainger 
GetUp!, which labels itself a “progressive” organisation and boasts a million members, has joined the campaign to change the date of Australia Day from January 26. 
They issued a press release advising sympathisers to join the “Invasion Day” marches, or go to work instead. People were not to celebrate. 
The group - along with Fremantle City Council, the left-wing Guardian website and a number of Aboriginal leaders including Warren Mundine - believe there should be no glorification of the arrival of the First Fleet in 1788. media_camera An Aboriginal protest flag is laid out at the southern end of Bondi Beach on Australia Day. Picture: Dylan Robinson 
Governor Lachlan Macquarie first commemorated the achievement of Sir Arthur Phillip landing here with a 21-gun salute and a ball. Ever since then celebrations have taken place under the guise of different names such as Anniversary Day and Foundation Day. 
It has been a public holiday since 1838, became officially known as Australia Day in 1946 and in 1994 was made uniform across the country. 
In Brisbane, a several thousand people gathered outside Parliament House for the annual Invasion Day March. 
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were joined by those from a variety of cultures to oppose the celebration of January 26 as Australia’s national day. media_camera People march through Brisbane. Picture: Peter Wallis media_camera The Brisbane rally. Picture: Peter Wallis 
Members of the local Aboriginal community used the opening address to voice their grievances about several issues, including the upcoming Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast, deaths in custody and education. 
Charles Hegarty, an Aboriginal man who has lived in Brisbane his whole life, said he and his family had attended as a show of support for “our people”. “Hopefully something comes out of it,” he said. 
“We need to get our own land back, where we came from.” The Invasion Day March has taken place every Australia Day in Brisbane since 1970. 
The theme for 2017 is resist, revive, decolonise. 
The march will proceed through the city and across the river to West End. 
MORE IN OPINION 
CELEBRATE AUSTRALIA DAY BY... BURNING THE FLAG 
Redfern Local Area Command Detective Superintendent Luke Freudenstein said organisers had been co-operative and the main focus was ensuring everyone was safe. 
“We are not expecting any trouble and we are sure it will be a peaceful event,” Det Supt Freudenstein said. 
“We just want to make sure the march complies with road blocks so nobody gets out into oncoming traffic and gets injured or puts our officers in harms way to help them.” media_camera People march through Brisbane. Picture Peter Wallis media_camera Protesters march through central Brisbane. Picture: AAP Image/Dan Peled media_camera The Invasion Day rally in Brisbane. Picture: Peter Wallis 
Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce was among those to rubbish calls to change the date today , saying it’s “political correctness gone mad”. 
The Nationals Leader’s message to anyone lobbying for the date to change from January 26 was: “If you don’t like it, go to work or do something else”. 
Speaking from his Tamworth home in NSW, Mr Joyce told 2GB radio in Sydney he was sick of people trying to make others feel guilty about celebrating Australia Day. media_camera An Australian naval ship in front of the Opera House this morning. Picture: Richard Dobson media_camera The annual ferry race takes place on Australia Day 2017. Picture: Richard Dobson media_camera It was an early barbie start for these true blue Aussies at Collaroy beach this morning. Picture: John Grainger How do you celebrate Australia day? 2:54 
A group of culturally diverse Australians are asked how they celebrate Australia Day January 25th 2017
